Updated by Jacqueline Rider for compliance with DACS and ACM Required Elements for Archival Description
New York University Archives
George Schwartz Papers
Schwartz, George
MC.217
0.5 linear feet in one manuscript box
1921-1925 George Schwartz received his Bachelor of Science with honors in biology from New York University (NYU) in 1925. This collection contains materials relating to undergraduate biology courses in which he was enrolled 1921-1925, such as histology and embryology, as well as his honors thesis and various other lab work and papers. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Materials are in English.
Access Restrictions
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records.
Arrangement
Folders are arranged in their original loose chronological order.
Biographical Note
George Schwartz received his Bachelor of Science with honors in biology from New York University (NYU) in 1925. He graduated from Bellevue Medical College in 1929. While at NYU, he participated in activities such as the Politics Club, the Menorah Society, the Junior Show, the Paint and Powder Club, and the Stuyvesant Club.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in repository; documentation concerning provenance of these materials is unavailable.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); George Schwartz Papers; MC 217; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.
Scope and Content Note
This collection consists of one box containing class materials from George Schwartz's undergraduate biology classes 1921-1925. Consisting mostly of handwritten lecture notes, it includes other materials, such as lab work and typed papers. Also included is his 1925 honors thesis.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, (212) 998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.
Processing Information
Processing information before 2019 is unavailable.
